A brief overview of Stranger of Paradise's characters:
Jack: A healer from FFXIV.
Ash: Possesses 50% of the team's brain cells.
Jed: Jack's kinda sus husband.
Neon: Jack and Jed's chunni adopted daughter.
Sophia: Has the other 50% of the team's brain cells.

So Stranger of Paradise has an interesting plot, and the hungy for Chaos stuff is a joy, but we need to talk about how the gameplay kicks fucking ass. The only other Final Fantasy with an action combat system of this caliber is Final Fantasy 7 Remake.

A guide to playing Stranger of Paradise Sage correctly:
Cast three buffs before a boss fight.
Cast three attack spells during the first phase of the boss fight.
Get your MP back during phase 1.
Use the Seal of Blood Command Ability.
Cast Ultima.
Enjoy the end of mission scene.

Abilities other than Affinity+ and Mastery for your job ability seem to be useable on any job. Weapon-based abilities of course require you to have the appropriate weapon. Command abilities appear to be universal.

Also, since all the starting jobs are 1:1 matches with the weapon you're using, this isn't clear: weapon movesets are not linked to your job. Sword will control the same on every job you equip with a sword. Jobs are one (1) unique move and a shopping list of abilities.

My #StrangerofParadise advice is to push through the first mission even if you're struggling. The weapon tutorials that will teach you how your weapons actually work are only available after that point.

Obviously neither works during multiplayer, but it's proof that #ELDENRING could absolutely have a pause button for all the adults with actual responsibilities trying to enjoy it.

Using PS1 notation, the fastest way to pause in #ELDENRING: Select, Select, down, X.
Only works when you aren't in danger (and can open your map).
When in danger, this will get it done: Start, X, Select, Up, X.

These open the Menu Explanation tutorials, which pause the game.

Maybe the absolute wildest thing to me is that you spend so long running at the final boss that I had to scorch every single one of its attacks into my muscle memory, so at this point, I'm pretty sure I could obliterate it no problem first or second try.
But in this metaphor, the hardest parts of Elden Ring, imo, are over-spiced.

And like, yeah, these challenges can be overcome, definitely, I fuckin' did it, but I've never come to Souls games for difficulty. I've always come to them for exploration and aesthetics - the difficulty is just a spice that reinforces the flavor.
The open world segments are such chill-ass vibes comparatively, that it's just bizarre to walk into a dungeon and go "oh, right, Dark Souls 3. Fuck."
I think my biggest problem with Elden Ring could also be solved by increasing every piece of armor in the game's negation stats by 1.5 or even 2 times.

For illustration, after putting on the heaviest armor I could while maintaining midroll with 35 Endurance and Godrick's Rune on to bump that up to 40, endgame bosses could often three or even two shot me. That's just too much damage imo.

Vigor is such an important stat for survival in Elden Ring that I don't know why it's still in the game. Every character needs to hit 60 Vigor. Instead, your HP should just go up every time you level up, it would achieve the same effect.
Now that I've beaten it, it's time to enter the Criticism Phase of liking Elden Ring.

Mt. Gelmir's boss music is just Zelda battle music and it really highlights how much Elden Ring can be taken as a direct sequel to The Legend of Zelda 1.

Like, there's obviously more to it than that, but being lost in an obscured world full of secrets, making character build choices with a large degree of freedom, and deliberate pattern-based combat are not new ideas. The particular synthesis is new, but the DNA can be traced.
The mystification of From Software games is wild to me. It's just the ideas of The Legend of Zelda (NES), Dragon Quest 3 (NES) and Castlevania 1 (NES) in one package.

From Software action RPGs are invested in making as many choices as possible viable and giving the player as much information as possible to make those choices. Some people are simply not interested in making those kinds of choices, and you can't "fix" that.

I think, fundamentally, players want to know whether the thing they just picked up is better than the thing they already have. Problem is, in From Software games, the answer to that question is always, always, always "it depends on what you define as better."

There's a ton of information on the stat screen, and I get that it's a lot, but there's a help button that will tell you, in detail, what everything on that screen means. It's even split into different sections pertaining to different topics.

I guess you could start by offering a simplified weapon stat screen where you hide the damage types a weapon doesn't have. But guard and defense properties are relevant for every piece of equipment because it's either armor OR you could theoretically block with it.

I'm sympathetic to the fact that Elden Ring's mechanics can be dense and intimidating for new players, but I don't know how you solve that without either reducing the player expression possible in the game or outright hiding more of how the game functions.

AC is fundamentally about balancing the speed of your damage output with how long you can output damage. If you try to use a bazooka against MTs, you'll run out, but if you use a gatling gun against an AC, there's a good chance you lose the damage race.

Like, imagine an Armored Core game with a system you can interact with to find out in advance that "oh hey, there's extremely going to be an enemy AC ambush at the end of this mission, so be ready for that."

I want to see a mecha action game with the approach to intel that High Fleet has. Just take Armored Core with all of its "hey it's basically impossible to avoid taking damage because guns" and marry that to the ability to know what's coming in different degrees of accuracy.

So the biggest problem in Armored Core is winning the intel battle. Which is to say, you can't without trying a mission, seeing what's in it, inevitably failing, and then coming back with a different build suited for the battle.

@tatsunical It's Sega's fault.
They had six button Genesis controllers with buttons labeled:
XYZ
ABC
Then for the Dreamcast they took off Z and C, and rearranged the buttons into the cross-shaped format the SNES controller used, but kept their button-labeling scheme.

By "MMOs" I am, of course, referring to the one MMO that exists, FFXIV.
FFXI is an interesting thing to visit because it's NOT like that. FFXI doesn't care that as a warrior, you have nothing to do. You picked the guy that does reliable auto-attack damage, so get to it.

MMOs are a wild genre of JRPG because it's less like you're fighting enemies and more like you're playing a mini-game designed just for you that might be completely different from everyone else's mini-game, and if everyone involved does at least okay at their mini-game, you win.
reading a post from 2003 about how FFXI Red Mage's Convert has a ten minute cooldown so "they're able to use it quite often"

In Rhapsodies of Vana'Diel, every single time you need to talk to someone, fight a monster, watch a cutscene, or just walk somewhere else, it counts as a new mission with its own description. It's structured like FFXIV quests, just without quest markers.

For instance, there is one national mission at rank 4. It involves several side quests, several dungeons, and several boss fights, all of which are summed up in the mission's three sentences of description.

Rhapsodies of Vana'Diel is fascinating because it's one of the latest things in FFXI, but it's also intended to be experienced alongside each of the prior campaigns of FFXI.

So you get to see how FFXI's mission design evolved alongside a constant reminder of its endpoint.

Sometimes FFXI is a little surreal. Climbing up Delkfutt Tower, which could be charitably described as "monochrome," and saw a Lightning Sprite and my brain became temporarily confused as to which FF MMO I was playing.

Like, sure, my character is a 50th level Warrior and Red Mage, but there are spells I could THEORETICALLY cast that I'm never ever going to cast because they're prohibitively expensive. Sure, I'm Windurst's ambassador, but that's not a paid position, I can't afford Dispel.

I figured it out! #FFXI feels the closest to D&D the series has ever been since the first game. There's that flavor of a fantasy world where your character and the power they accumulate still make logical sense, and the world is dangerous and difficult to traverse.

I have seen credits roll on every mainline Final Fantasy release except for #FFXI and it's wild how it feels like one of the most antiquated games in the series.

My fondest memory of FF11 is two other players coordinating to get my first character's level 20-ass through a forest of level 30+ enemies so I could get my Chocobo ASAP because no matter which direction you approach the main city from, there's no way to do it safely at level 20.

Shout out to @gridcarto, the single best program I've found for doing this kind of mapping with very similar flexibility to Etrian Odyssey's purpose-built tools. I've used it to help in full runs of Megami Tensei 1 & 2, an abandoned Wizardry 5 run, and an ongoing SMT1 run.

This is the secret Etrian Odyssey was trying to communicate via a new generation of classic dungeon crawlers, and it's no less fun to do this kind of information gathering when mapping early SMT, Wizardry, or newer games like Stranger of Sword City.

No matter how hard a dungeon crawler is, if you're making your own map, you've now solidified information that the game can never take away from you under any circumstances. If you get wiped out, you can try again, better and faster.

The thing that makes first-person dungeon crawlers kick ass is a thing not all players will be willing to engage with: drawing your own maps. Things that are frustrating without a self-drawn map (holes, teleporters, dark zones), are information gathering with one.

@mintmakesthings Chaos route ending

The arrival of demons in SMT is never an imposition of outside ideas, and neutral is never rejecting and conquering those ideas. Demons reveal the truth of the world, and the neutral route is pushing them back under a conveniently demons-shaped rug.

The forces of Law can only do what they do if the forces of Chaos are correct and Law happens to be the stronger force. Similarly, if Chaos wins the struggle, a force sufficiently powerful to impose their own Law on the world is an inevitably. They're an ouroboros.

I'm turning this into a joke because I don't think I have a whole essay about it in me, but once you understand anything about power politics, it's obvious that Chaos' "only the strong shall rule!" is literally just how political entities operate.

Shin Megami Tensei games with Law, Chaos, and Neutral ending routes do not represent opposing forces but the face society presents, the true face of society, and the inability to imagine any possible alternatives. In this essay I will -

Just absolutely fascinated that there hasn't been a finished Final Fantasy game other than 14 with its infinite revenue stream since 10.

And then Square just releases DQ11, a JRPG that, so far as I understand, made zero concessions to HD development realities and is complete.

Some of you may be wondering "wait are you gonna like... play every Dragon Quest game basically in a row as some kind of bizarre extended celebration of Sugiyama's death???"

To answer that question, I bought Dragon Quest 11 S before I started DQ5.

@mintmakesthings I actually played a little bit of DQ7's remake on the 3DS when it came out. Enough to know that Maribel in the intro has more personality than I've seen out of Milly, Ashlynn, and Nevan combined so far in DQ6.

But because of that, DQ6 feels like the most "standard" Dragon Quest? Like if you asked me for the "standard" Final Fantasy, it's FF4 easy, right when the first major design shift happened in the series. DQ6 is the standard one because they ran out of kick ass ideas.

DQ6: You meet some people kind of arbitrarily and then they're in your party for, uh, reasons?
It actually opens up with a compelling hook for wanting to get to know these characters and then their personalities are just... nothing.

DQ5: Supplements the very limited party member selection with monsters; available party members are deeply personal to the protagonist, consisting of a few close friends and the protagonist's own family.

DQ4: Multi-perspective story where each character is treated as the protagonist of their own story, culminating in a final chapter where your own character joins them in an ensemble cast of characters you are deeply familiar with and endeared to.

These three games can only really be understood as dungeon crawling adventure games at their heart, expecting the player to piece together clues from around their worlds that are a single puzzle asking to be solved.

DQ1: Single character ur-JRPG
DQ2: Three character party with zero personality, infamously imbalanced.
DQ3: Four character party, only one of which you don't invent whole cloth. Again, zero personality.
Dragon Quest 6 is maybe the weirdest Dragon Quest game ever released because it's the first one that is a normal JRPG with an fairly trope-y and uninteresting cast.

In conclusion, have the coldest take in the history of time: turns out famously beloved JRPG Dragon Quest V is good.
The fact that adult John DraQueV even spends some time going on adventures with his best bro for a while also feels like it's trying to express a certain true-to-life dynamic of early adulthood.

DQ5's party design is interesting in that it's practically the exact opposite of DQ4's varied and colorful cast, but it means that the the player's relationship with the characters who DO have opinions (that is to say, the humans) is far more intimate, and that makes sense.
Let it be known that the canonical wife of my DQ5 character, Hank, is Bianca. I think Deborah would be more fun of a character long-term, but I wanted a more true-to-the-original experience.

From what I know about the GBC, I have to assume that the attack animations take up the entire graphical memory that isn't being used by the UI or stationary enemy BG tiles, a use of resources that could only be accomplished by a RPG with an otherwise sparse combat screen.

Dragon Quest 3 GBC's enemy attack animations are absolutely incredible. The games have obviously different priorities, but I can't believe the platform that had Pokemon Gold/Silver/Crystal's animations also had these.

There's a push for JRPGs that let you skip non-boss encounters, and there should be space for that in the genre. I think games should also exist in the JRPG space that are about the endurance match against a dungeon instead of just doing your MP taxes before the boss.

Here's a hot take: the assumption that a dungeon must have a boss fight in it is a disservice to JRPGs. It encourages players to hoard their resources for a possibly only theoretical future battle, devalues non-boss encounters, and encourages players to disengage from them.
There are many cases of JRPGs that people say require grinding that just simply don't if you're willing to spend the resources available to you and are occasionally willing to retreat.

playing classic JRPGs again with a more developed willingness to engage with game design as it exists in front of me is just, so good
it's absolutely excellent

@mintmakesthings Yes. It is not very helpful. Usually it only serves to delay the cartoon chase scene.

Like, the SA-X was a terrifying opponent because every encounter with it is like "I'm not sure how long ago I saved, if I fuck this up, there is a Problem." It could be that way because it was used sparingly and with impact.

So every EMMI encounter becomes an absurd cartoon chase scene where the goal is to do normal Metroid things while instant death Shadow Mario is following you.

It's not even tense or scary! They plop you right back outside the EMMI Zone when you die!

There are some tools in the game that I think are supposed to help you deal with an EMMI, but more often than not the end result is "ah this time I died instantly the EMMI was not aware of my presence before it killed me."

The fact that making a single mistake against an EMMI means instant death is miserable. Running away from EMMIs are miserable. Trying to parse what directions I can even go while dealing with an EMMI is miserable.

I don't want to rain on people's parades, Metroid Dread has a lot going for it that is good.
But personally, every time I have to deal with an EMMI, all I can think about is how much it sucks.

For those who are wondering why I didn't write about this on my blog: I'm very aware of the fact that it could rapidly devolve into me being negative about games I recognize are good but just Are Not For Me, and I don't want that to be the body of work I have made.

But slowly whittling away at one dude for literally minutes during brief openings in the enemy's formation because my sword number is not high enough to go in a direction the game told me to go is miserable.

And yes, it is theoretically possible to win out-of-depth encounters in Dragon's Dogma. I have fought a single group of bandits for like ten minutes with all my pawns dead on the ground because my character is the only one being piloted by a human who can dodge.

There was a sentiment for a while that DD was like Dark Souls, but balanced for "regular people," and like no, it isn't. DS lets you use your personal skill or your character's build to succeed. DD cares about how big your number is, and that's it.

And that point is like 4ish hours in when the game goes "here's a side quest that sounds like you should go do it RIGHT NOW because it's an urgent situation involving a character your character ostensibly cares about! Also the bandits and monsters along the way WILL body you."

Every day I'm like "what if I tried Dragon's Dogma again and liked it this time???"
And every time I get to the exact same point in the game and get frustrated that my skill level at the combat is significantly less important than my numbers and stop playing.
looking at my system clock like "Ah shit, there are sixteen hours before I have to go to sleep? I can't believe I've already wasted my entire day!"

Under the right circumstances, Tenno even work with the factions they're fighting! It's often easier in a large-scale conflict for Tenno to thumb the scale than blow it up because, again, Tenno are operatives, not an army.
Tenno strike back at corruption in the solar system, but only so that individual communities can express and maintain greater autonomy.

Critically, while there are factions that are friendly with the Tenno (including splinter factions from the major factions AND the angry hive mind), the Tenno themselves do not have a civilization they are in charge of.

But observing what the Tenno actually do, it's pretty straightforward. There are two major factions (and also an angry hive mind) and you spend all your time interfering with their objectives and performing outright assassinations.

Warframe is the one of these games where your position in the world is both the most surface-level suspicious and morally solid. You kind of have to piece together the Tenno's goals for yourself, since you can't ask questions and no one provides motivation.

Obviously, you're encouraged to frame everything narratively, otherwise why not go like play a video game or something, but this makes the game's loop risking penalties by trying to increase progress until your resources are too low or you're confident in the results.
To advance a progress track, you have to make moves with Action rolls that can do that; IE if you want to advance a "Fight the wolves" progress track, you'd likely want to use combat moves.

So it looks like the core of Ironsworn is Progress Moves, moves that determine the outcome of a journey, a battle, a vow, or your character's retirement.
And those Moves have you make rolls based on a Progress track.

The thing that made me interested was the game insisting you can play solo, in a group without a GM, and in a group with a GM, and I'm curious to see what that looks like. Feels like GMless play is a pretty... viable leap that move-based narrative-first games could make.

Spending some time today checking out Ironsworn, a free GM...-neutral? tabletop RPG for 1-4 player characters. Looks like the structure of moves is very PbtA, so I'm hoping to run a one-shot for myself by the end of the day. I will report back.

@tinyvalor I haven't PLAYED Oblivion in a long time, though, so me vouching for it should be taken with a grain of salt.

@tinyvalor Oblivion is probably the best one for a newcomer in terms of friction:fun. It's still a game with a really bad level up system you should probably replace with a mod, but TES hadn't yet been successful enough to have all its personality scrubbed off by a committee.
Skyrim's lore is one of its strong points, but unfortunately for it, it shares that lore with TES 1, 2, 3, & 4, Redguard, Battlespire 1 & 2, and Online, so you can get that lore in many other places!

I'm not talking about a reward loop, either; I'm talking interesting stories, locations, and characters. The game has no personality and treats every thing you do with the same level of unbearably self-aggrandizing Epic Norse Dude tone.

Skyrim, as designed without any mods, is easily game with the worst how hard is it to play vs how worth continuing to play it ratio in the entirety of the games I've played.
Skyrim makes you work so hard and gives you so little in return.

Resident Evil 8 is really easy to play. A supremely chill experience. I don't think that's what RE should be though? One section of the game was stressful (House Beneviento). I spent the rest of the game commenting to my roommate "Oh, hey, it's regular guys again?"

And the absolute wildest thing is that they set up a few RE4/5 style battle arenas late game and... you can just leave. Like, they let you walk out of the arena and fight from the entrance where just one dude can get to you at a time.

It definitely feels like they're terrified to put you up against more than a couple of enemies at a time, and the RE8 roster is not dangerous enough to support small enemy groups. It's like this weird halfway between RE7 and RE4.

The game plays really well, all the guns feel good to use, but every enemy feels like a basic enemy? Even the three advanced Molded types from RE7 put up more of a fight than the most dangerous RE8 enemies.

The Lady D section is the best section of the game, but it's also like Diet Resident Evil 7, with the world's least effective pursuers.

The factory is the second part of the game that feels like Resident Evil, and it ends with the stupidest thing that's ever happened in one.

Most zombie fiction: a zombie showed up and the world ended
Resident Evil: nah, man, they could make like a huge tentacle demon the size of a boat and sneaky zombies with razor-sharp extendo-tongues and mind-control parasites and society would not significantly change
RE6 might be a pretty bad Resident Evil game (and an incredible Resident Evil Mercenaries mode), but the things it says about the mundanity of BOWs in the setting is incredible.

Like, there would be some obligatory thoughts and prayers news coverage, and then some absolute ghoul on the news would talk about how this is the poors' fault somehow and that's why we shouldn't feel bad about dropping this nuke on the city despite possible survivors.
Resident Evil 6 is a model for how a zombie outbreak would work in real life, primarily because it nails how modern society would give basically no shits about it.

@kzinssiebroiler No! But I'm aware that it has a different reloading mechanic as well. I didn't bring it up because I don't like to talk about games I don't have personal experience with.
Imagine practicing reloads like practicing combos in a fighting game.

Standardized control conventions are Good for video games, but I feel like there's a world out there with a multiplayer FPS where "how hard is the gun to reload in combat" is a part of the game's balance.

Thinking about how the friction introduced by the simulationist approach Receiver and Receiver 2 take with reloading (and everything else) make them feel so much different from every other non-VR shooter on the market.

If you like FFT's tone more than FFTA's, the Tactics Ogre games are also much better versions of what FFT offers, ESPECIALLY if the early political intrigue bits that are eventually abandoned is why you prefer FFT over FFTA.

The important takeaway here:
Though laws get way too aggressive late game (and there are hacks that fix this), Final Fantasy Tactics Advance is a better game than Final Fantasy Tactics on pretty much every level.

Final Fantasy Tactics is a game which can be rapidly broken, and the game's solution to that problem after a certain point is creating enemies that can reliably one-shot your units.

It's an arms race against the devs: how early in a fight can you mash an instant win button?

Breaking the Wiegraf fight via AI manipulation and stacking buffs long enough to gain FIFTEEN LEVELS during the fight, only to find out that the Wiegraf fight was not nearly as difficult as the fight immediately following it broke me.

Bringing a broken Monk build that could deal 200~ damage in a single attack to the Riovanes Wiegraf fight and realizing that build was not sufficiently broken to actually complete it weakened my resolve.

There are a ton of people who think Final Fantasy Tactics is an incredible game.

I used to, too. Then I tried to actually FINISH it.

@atlaspolara You absolutely need some latex gloves to work with acrylic paints, and some alligator clips on sticks to hold the part while you paint; you WILL get paint on parts you didn't intend otherwise. Take it from me, who learns this lesson again on every single model.

@atlaspolara I wouldn't recommend Gundam paint markers for anything other than touch-ups though, like covering up plastic nub marks.

If I need to paint a large chunk of plastic for some reason, I use acrylic paint markers. They take forever to dry, but they're easy to work with.

@atlaspolara If you're doing traditional (ie non-marker) panel lining, then yes, it's a required part of the process. The good thing about Gundam Markers of all kinds is that they are pre-thinned so you can just use them. If you get Gundam paint markers, make sure to shake them really well.

I tried a bunch of Pico-8 shmups and a lot of them are Tyrian style. Nothing wrong with Tyrian, but I don't like it. 
There was one Touhou fan game which was solid as heck but the bullets are as big as your character, making it hard to see where you (and your hitbox) are.

R-Type 1 and 2 are great examples of "if you make your defensive option too strong you have to make your game BRUTAL" come to think of it.

I don't recommend R-Type 1 or 2 to ANYONE. I need to spend time with R-Type Delta and onward to decide whether they're fit for consumption.

Because GB Studio can support so few projectiles and enemies on screen at a time, I can't afford to be TOO forgiving, but I also like shooters that let you protect yourself to a degree (both versions of Charge in Zero Ranger, the Force in R-Type, Shield in Gradius)
(obviously if you get hit without an armor block you lose a life)

but there are slots between each option, and spending a power-up there will place an Armor block, and if you get hit you lose your Armor block and everything to the right of it (so it incentivizes putting it as far right in the bar as possible)

My thought is a shorter power-up bar without any mutually exclusive power-ups.
Rapid Fire Up / Missile / Double / something else?

Thinking about Space Barker's power-up system. My own love of Gradius and the Gameboy's limitations mean that a Gradius-style "pick up a single power-up currency and spend them on upgrades" is probably the way to go.

Consequently, the next big step is capping player projectiles. Right now the player can fire all they way and prevent enemies from firing.
Big limitation: cranking up the projectile count above *checks notes* five causes GB Studio to lag (acceptable behavior in gameplay). Above 11 causes crashing (not acceptable behavior in gameplay).

Addendum: I have no idea how to feel about Darius. Chronicle Saviours seems cool, but I don't know if it's good? Like, I've never played a game where I've been confused as to how the shield works before. Also its thousands of levels get very samey quickly.

Bullet hell shooters are all about dodging and pattern recognition, but method shooters are all about logistics. "Where do I want to be to not get hit by thousands of bullets" vs. "how do I hit that guy so that a FIFTH bullet is not on screen threatening my life"

I gotta say, as much I as appreciate a bullet hell, method shooters ala Gradius and R-Type are where it's at for me. Too bad basically no one makes these any more. Never mind Satazius and R-Type Final 2 on the Switch, ignore those for the sake of my argument.

Nemesis 2 indeed has Stage 1 as its most kick ass single stage, but what the maps I was looking at didn't get across was that stages 3, 4, 5, and 6 flow into each other seamlessly; you're in control the entire time.
Notably, Nemesis lets you give yourself up to 99 lives in the options menu, and is pretty chill, so it's great for shmup beginners.

I have now completed both Nemesis and Nemesis 2 for the Gameboy. Also known as Gradius and Gradius: Interstellar Assault / Gradius 2: Return of the Hero respectively.

They now sit there with Link's Awakening as some of my favorite Gameboy games.
RT @GigaBashGame: "The recent disturbances have disrupted the relative peace in Tarabak. Thundatross has stepped in to intervene in the sit…
and memorizing all of Stage 4 and 6, of course

Gradius has various shield types and R-Type has the absolute defense granted by your Force, but you always have to decide whether you want it in front of you, behind you, or being used offensively.

Lots of R-Type for me was figuring out when it was safe to relocate my Force.

No matter how many lives it took you, beating a checkpoint shmup still feels like you beat it instead of cheesed through it.

Also, with the two above examples, they both have really strong defensive options, which is rare for shmups beyond "bomb if you're scared."
Huge shout-out to checkpoint shmups like Gradius and R-Type. Unlike a lot of modern shooters, they won't let you credit feed to the ending, since you get sent back to a checkpoint every time you die.

My project to upgrade GB Studio's horishmup capabilities is going some places.
What I've built is primarily for a hori-shmup, but once I've covered what I think most users would want supported, I'll be releasing that code on itch.
, re-rendering the player sprite only when they aren't moving opposite the camera, and omnidirectional camera movement driven by player movement ala top-down mode when the camera isn't moving.

I'm working on fixing that; so far just working on shmup.c, I've gotten the camera to push the player so movement parallel to the camera is possible, subpixel diagonal movement, autodetection of left/right/no camera movement...

So GB Studio's current built-in shmup code is a little unusual, as it's kind of hijacking player movement to push the camera. Consequently, the player can't move parallel to the camera or the whole illusion is busted.
Also, there's only one camera speed.

Very excited about Final Fantasy III getting a modern port. FFIII DS isn't bad, but it's also different enough that I'd call it a different game.

FFIII's job system is less about player expression and more about flexibility when responding to challenges.
to be clear, these games have 20 years separating them, but this is a rare enough choice in JRPGs that my other option was comparing Chrono Cross to, like FF13, which isn't that much closer.

Chrono Cross: Does this poorly. There's an accuracy vs damage system for regular attacks, but you can literally set it to auto, and since unspent battle resources can be spent on healing, you can mash through battles and come out the other side with MORE resources.

MonHunStories2: Does this well. Battles pile on rewards and HP management is still a factor. Individual battles feature the Power/Speed/Technical attack system which forces players to engage with a system in regular battles even if they aren't using resources.
you gotta be real careful taking MP out of a JRPG because regular combat can feel meaningless without that long-term resource management

It's okay if you don't want to say anything with your game beyond having it be a game that people can play.

But the western AAA space has a bad habit of saying a lot with their game and then assuring people in their marketing that they have nothing to say.
When you try to tell stories like this, confronting your own world view and the world as it exists is inevitable. And sometimes you find struggles you didn't expect to find.

There's a major theme from the Friends At The Table season Twilight Mirage about not having any alibis. And to me it meant not making any excuses for the world view expressed in the storytelling. And that has stuck with me as both deeply influential and a monumental challenge.

hot #gunpla tip: ignore the order the instructions are in
1st: weapons & backpack
2nd: legs & arms
3rd: waist
4th: upper torso
5th: head

this way you do the most boring parts early on when you have a ton of excitement for the kit
